title: Working with Entitlements
content:
In the context of Customer Service Management (CSM), entitlements refer to the predefined rights, permissions, or services that a customer is entitled to receive as part of their relationship with a company. These entitlements outline what services, support, or benefits a customer can access based on factors such as their service agreement, product purchases, subscription type, or contract.

Key aspects

  1. Product or Service Coverage: Entitlements can specify which products or services are covered under customer support. For instance, a customer who has purchased an extended warranty may be entitled to free repairs for a certain period or support for additional features.
  2. Support Channels: Entitlements may also determine which channels of support the customer can use. For example, some customers may be entitled to support via phone and chat, while others may only have access to email support or a self-service portal.
  3. Number of Requests or Cases: Entitlements can also limit the number of cases, incidents, or requests a customer can submit within a given time period. For example, a customer may have a plan that entitles them to five support cases per year, after which additional charges may apply.

How entitlements work

In OpenText Service Management, we differentiate between Entitlement Rules and Entitlement records.

Entitlement records document what level of support and for which products a customer and its users are entitled to. In OpenText Service Management context, this means entitlements track which products a customer can see articles or request services. It is also possible to delegate entitlement records to another companies, such as partners or child companies. Delegation allows the owner company to entitle the related parties to receive the same permissions for service consumption, as granted to the owner company.

The Entitlement Rules tab of the People module ensures that offerings, knowledge articles, service definitions, categories, and custom themes in the service portal are available to relevant audiences in specified locations, belonging to specified user groups, belonging to a specified company or have specified roles, independent of a purchased product. For more details about Entitlement Rules, click here.

Entitlement Rules and Entitlement records can be combined. By combining both methods following use case are possible:

  • Have location-specific services per product
    For example, Knowledge Article A and Offering A are available for Product A for the Asian market, whereas Knowledge Article B and Offering B are available for Product A only for the European market.
  • Have group-specific services per product
    For example, Knowledge Article A and Offering A are available for Product A for Group A, whereas knowledge Article B and Offering B are available for Product A for Group B.
  • Have company-specific services per product
    For example, Knowledge Article A and Offering A are available for Product A for Company A and B, whereas Knowledge Article B and Offering B are available for Product A for Company C and D.

Use case 1 - Customer entitlement

In this use case, a customer owns several products. These products are tracked as product instances. A product instance is related to a product model, which serves as the template for the instance. The product model is related with articles and offerings to control permission via entitlements to those customers who have purchased the product model. The partner ASP is then entitled to create and update requests on behalf of the customer ACME.

Let's assume we have the following data entered into the system.

Based on the above data two entitlement records with the permissions for the users have been created.

As a result of this configuration, the users of company ACME can see the following data in the service portal:

Permission for item ACME_User 1 ACME_User 2
Can view articles Article A yes no
Can view articles Article B no yes
Can see offerings to create requests Offering A yes no
Can see offerings to create requests Offering B no yes
Can view requests for Product instance SW Product 1 - Instance 1 yes no
Can view requests for Product instance SW Product 2 - Instance 2 yes no
Can view requests for Product instance SW Product 3 - Instance 3 no yes
Can update requests for Product instance SW Product 1 - Instance 1 yes no
Can update requests for Product instance SW Product 2 - Instance 2 yes no
Can update requests for Product instance SW Product 3 - Instance 3 no yes

Use case 2 - Customer entitlement delegated to a partner

This use case is similar to the first one. The difference is that customer ACME has created a company relation to partner ASP and has delegated each entitlement to that partner. With this setup, users from the partner ASP can get the same permissions for the entitled products than users from company ACME.

Let's assume we have the following data entered into the system.

Based on the above data two entitlement records with the permissions for the users have been created.

As a result of this configuration, the users of company ACME and ASP can see the following data in the service portal :

Permission for item ACME_User 1 ACME_User 2 ASP_User 1 ASP_User 2
Can view articles Article A yes no yes no
Can view articles Article B no yes no yes
Can see offerings to
create requests
 Offering A yes no yes no
Can see offerings to
create requests
 Offering B no yes no yes
Can view requests
for Product instance
 SW Product 1 - Instance 1 yes no yes no
Can view requests
for Product instance
 SW Product 2 - Instance 2 yes no yes no
Can view requests
for Product instance
 SW Product 3 - Instance 3 no yes no yes
Can update requests
for Product instance		 SW Product 1 - Instance 1 yes no yes no
Can update requests
for Product instance		 SW Product 2 - Instance 2 yes no yes no
Can update requests
for Product instance		 SW Product 3 - Instance 3 no yes no yes

Use case 3 - Multi service provider entitlements with customer delegation

In this use case, a Multi Service Provider (MSP) owns the products and entitlements. The MSP is serving different customers. The MSP entitles some users of its customers to consume services directly. The MSP has a company relation to two customers. Each user of the customers has different permissions.

Let assume we have the following data entered into the system.

Based on the above data two entitlement records with the permissions for the users have been created.

As a result of this configuration, the users of companies MSP, ACME and EMCA can see the following data in the in the service portal:

Permission for item MSP_User 1 MSP_User 2 ACME_User 1 EMCA_User 1
Can view articles Article A yes yes yes Yes
Can view articles Article B yes yes no yes
Can see offerings to
create requests
 Offering A yes yes no no
Can see offerings to
create requests
 Offering B yes yes no yes
Can view requests
for Product instance
 SW Product 1 - Instance 1 yes yes yes yes
Can view requests
for Product instance
 SW Product 2 - Instance 2 yes yes yes ye
Can view requests
for Product instance
 SW Product 3 - Instance 3 yes yes no yes
Can update requests
for Product instance		 SW Product 1 - Instance 1 yes yes no no
Can update requests
for Product instance		 SW Product 2 - Instance 2 yes yes no no
Can update requests
for Product instance		 SW Product 3 - Instance 3 yes yes no yes
